articles.headline: A 21st-Century Migrant’s Essentials: Food, Shelter, Smartphone
articles.snippet: For the tens of thousands of migrants flooding into Europe, smartphone maps, global positioning apps, social media and WhatsApp have become essential tools.
articles.abstract: For the tens of thousands of migrants flooding into Europe, smartphone maps, global positioning apps, social media and WhatsApp have become essential tools.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELGRADE, Serbia — The tens of thousands of migrants who have flooded into the Balkans in recent weeks need food, water and shelter, just like the millions displaced by war the world over. But there is also one other thing they swear they cannot live without: a smartphone charging station.

articles.headline: Test for Donald Trump: Turning Crowds Into Real Voters
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump is putting in place a robust field operation in Iowa, but converting raucous crowds into votes in primaries and caucuses remains a challenge.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump is putting in place a robust field operation in Iowa, but converting raucous crowds into votes in primaries and caucuses remains a challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBUQUE, Iowa — Donald J. Trump, it is abundantly clear, is not a conventional candidate. And neither is his approach to recruiting campaign activists.

articles.headline: Political Risks May Foil Economic Reform in China
articles.snippet: There is scant historical evidence that an authoritarian, undemocratic government like China’s could pull off the kinds of reforms it is being called on to make.
articles.abstract: There is scant historical evidence that an authoritarian, undemocratic government like China’s could pull off the kinds of reforms it is being called on to make.

articles.headline: Inquiry Weighs Whether ISIS Analysis Was Distorted
articles.snippet: The inspector general is looking into a claim that military officials reworked assessments about the U.S.-led campaign in Iraq against ISIS to be more optimistic, according to several officials.
articles.abstract: The inspector general is looking into a claim that military officials reworked assessments about the U.S.-led campaign in Iraq against ISIS to be more optimistic, according to several officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon’s inspector general is investigating allegations that military officials have skewed intelligence assessments about the United States-led campaign in Iraq against the Islamic State to provide a more optimistic account of progress, according to several officials familiar with the inquiry.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Puerto Rico Turmoil Sinks Sewer Bond
articles.snippet: Puerto Rico will not go ahead with a $750 million bond, just days after asking the U.S. Supreme Court for the right to restructure its huge debt.
articles.abstract: Puerto Rico will not go ahead with a $750 million bond, just days after asking the U.S. Supreme Court for the right to restructure its huge debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: Up against a deadline to reveal its plan to restructure its staggering debt, Puerto Rico has decided not to move ahead with a controversial proposal to borrow an additional $750 million to pay for improvements to its water and sewer authority.

articles.headline: Signs, Long Unheeded, Now Point to Risks in U.S. Economy
articles.snippet: For more than a year now, signs pointing to an equity crisis were there for all to see.
articles.abstract: For more than a year now, signs pointing to an equity crisis were there for all to see.
articles.lead_paragraph: As investors scramble to make sense of the wild market swings in recent days, a number of financial experts argue that, for more than a year now, signs pointing to an equity crisis were there for all to see.

articles.headline: Soothing Talk by Federal Reserve Official Buoys Wall Street
articles.snippet: A Federal Reserve official suggested that September might be too soon to raise interest rates, and investors seemed to react by buying up stocks.
articles.abstract: A Federal Reserve official suggested that September might be too soon to raise interest rates, and investors seemed to react by buying up stocks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once again, the Federal Reserve helped save the day for investors.

articles.headline: The Upside of a Downturn in Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: Venture capitalists may actually welcome some of the consequences of leaner times, which could lower costs, decrease competition and toughen up start-ups.
articles.abstract: Venture capitalists may actually welcome some of the consequences of leaner times, which could lower costs, decrease competition and toughen up start-ups.
articles.lead_paragraph: In October 2008, in the early days of the last economic collapse, Sequoia Capital invited founders of technology companies to a frank meeting outlining the new global reality.

articles.headline: Donald Trump Gets Earful in Spanish as Latino Outlets Air Disdain
articles.snippet: Many Spanish-language news outlets no longer pretend to objectively cover Mr. Trump, who has made disparaging remarks about Mexican immigrants.
articles.abstract: Many Spanish-language news outlets no longer pretend to objectively cover Mr. Trump, who has made disparaging remarks about Mexican immigrants.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ricardo Sánchez, known as “El Mandril” on his Spanish drive-time radio show in Los Angeles, has taken to calling Donald J. Trump “El hombre del peluquín” — the man of the toupee.

articles.headline: Ex-Broadcaster Kills 2 on Air in Virginia Shooting; Takes Own Life
articles.snippet: Officials said a former colleague of Alison Parker and Adam Ward, a reporter and cameraman for WDBJ, shot and killed them as they broadcast live on Wednesday.
articles.abstract: Officials said a former colleague of Alison Parker and Adam Ward, a reporter and cameraman for WDBJ, shot and killed them as they broadcast live on Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROANOKE, Va. — He was a fired television reporter with a history of conflicts at work and rage apparently stoked by racial grievances. And when he sought revenge on Wednesday, gunning down two former colleagues, he used the tools of social media to ensure that his crime was broadcast live, recorded from multiple angles and posted online.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Richard Pérez-Peña and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: In-Flight Wi-Fi Prices Jump as Demand Surges
articles.snippet: Gogo, the top provider of in-flight Wi-Fi, says high demand and reliance on old technology have driven it to double peak prices in the last three years.
articles.abstract: Gogo, the top provider of in-flight Wi-Fi, says high demand and reliance on old technology have driven it to double peak prices in the last three years.
articles.lead_paragraph: During a Tuesday-morning flight in April from Los Angeles to New York, Christine Lu’s smartphone web browser loaded an unpleasant surprise: Gogo, the in-flight Wi-Fi provider, wanted to charge her $27 to use its service during the five-and-a-half-hour trip.

articles.headline: China’s Big Spenders Pull Back, as Stock Market Shudders
articles.snippet: China’s upper crust represents as much as a third of global luxury spending. The tumult in China’s financial markets is denting that, leaving retailers anxious.
articles.abstract: China’s upper crust represents as much as a third of global luxury spending. The tumult in China’s financial markets is denting that, leaving retailers anxious.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of Hong Kong’s busiest shopping streets winds past the Times Square center, under slick signs for brands like Mont Blanc, Cartier, Gucci and Burberry.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Amie Tsang
